results.abstract: USSR repts preparations are being successfully completed for joint Apollo-Soyuz mission in July '74 (S)
results.snippet: MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (UPI)--The preparations for the historic space rendezvous of astronauts from the United States and Sovient Union are being successfully completed, a member of the Soviet crew said today.
results.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (UPI)--The preparations for the historic space rendezvous of astronauts from the United States and Sovient Union are being successfully completed, a member of the Soviet crew said today.

results.abstract: cosmonauts visit Apollo spacecraft, Cape Canaveral; express confidence in readiness of Apollo; previous invitations to space complex had been declined, apparently because of Soviet unwillingness to reciprocate with invitations to Baikonur, desert launching facility in Soviet Republic of Kazakhstan; Amer astronauts will return visit by traveling to Baikonur in May; 10 members of Soviet team visit vehicle assembly bldg and firing room as well as pad from which rocket will be launched; fly to Johnson Space Center, Houston, to continue joint training until end of February (M)

headline.main: SOVIET SPACEMEN VISIT THE APOLLO; Also See Launching Pad on Busy Last Day in Florida  Train in Texas Today

results.snippet: CAPE CANAVERAL Fla., Feb. 10 Soviet astronauts climbed today into the Apollo, spacecraft that is scheduled to link up with their Soyuz craft during the joint Soviet-American spaceflight next July, and expressed confidence in its readiness.

byline.original: By VICTOR K. McELHENY Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: CAPE CANAVERAL Fla., Feb. 10 Soviet astronauts climbed today into the Apollo, spacecraft that is scheduled to link up with their Soyuz craft during the joint Soviet-American spaceflight next July, and expressed confidence in its readiness.

headline.main: Soviet-U.S. Space Flight Nearing Readiness Stage; Soviet-U.S. Space Flight Nearing Readiness Stage

results.snippet: HOUSTON, Feb. 14 With the Soviet space pilots scheduled to return home next Friday following their third training session in the United States, only a few major items remain to be worked out before the Soviet-American space venture scheduled for July...

byline.original: By VICTOR K. McELHENY Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Feb. 14 With the Soviet space pilots scheduled to return home next Friday following their third training session in the United States, only a few major items remain to be worked out before the Soviet-American space venture scheduled for July 15.

results.abstract: preparations for joint Apollo-Soyuz mission proceed smoothly at Cape Canaveral and at Houston Space Center as well as at Soviet launching site in Kazakhstan; few items remain to be worked out before scheduled July 15 launching; equipment, which includes Amer-mfrd docking module and complete 'backup' Soyuz spacecraft, already have been delivered to respective launching sites; control centers near Houston and Moscow will in Mar carry out 1st serious practice sessions on methods of coping with possible emergencies, using interpreters, telephones, teletype and TV channels; Amer astronauts will undertake 3d training session in USSR in Apr and tech leaders of project will carry out final rev of readiness in May; questions pertaining to flight's safety and its relevance to Amer interests are intensifying, but Soviet cosmonauts and officials are asserting that problem with Soyuz, epitomized by leaky valve that resulted in deaths of 3 cosmonauts of Soyuz 11 in '71, has been solved; Soviet officials cite evidence of 6 successful follow-up flights; Soviet tech dir Prof Konstantin D Bushuyev notes films of recent successful Soyuz docking in space have been shown to Amer engineers, and US astronaut Brig Gen Thomas P Stafford holds docking mechanism developed for flight is superior to those used on previous Soyuz or Apollo missions; relevance of joint venture to Amer interests discussed; political attractiveness of Apollo-Soyuz, which will make possible 1 more manned space mission in interval between Skylab and beginning of orbital flights by space shuttle in '79, noted; chief problems in organizing joint mission reptdly have been linguistic rather than technological; NASA has been forced to use computers for 'two-way' translations, from English to Russian and Russian to English; astronauts will be forced to rely on command of each other's languages to communicate; mission highlights revd; astronauts illus in training (L)

headline.main: Alcoa President Named To Chief Executive Post; People and Business

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HOTELS, BARS, MOTELS, NIGHT CLUBS AND RESTAURANTS

results.snippet: W.H. Krome George, 56, was named chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America yesterday at a board meeting in Pittsburgh. Mr. George, who will continue as Alcoa's president, will take over his new post on March 1.
results.lead_paragraph: W.H. Krome George, 56, was named chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America yesterday at a board meeting in Pittsburgh. Mr. George, who will continue as Alcoa's president, will take over his new post on March 1.

results.abstract: Jack Slater article on blind, popular singer Stevie Wonder; biog; career; his talent appraised; illus (L)

headline.main: To be young, gifted and blind; A sense of Wonder

results.snippet: Stevie Wonder, alternately playing two futuristic musical instruments and occasionally joining the several conversations which swirled about him, sat in his tiny, crowded dressing room composing music. He was writing a song tentatively titled "If...
results.lead_paragraph: Stevie Wonder, alternately playing two futuristic musical instruments and occasionally joining the several conversations which swirled about him, sat in his tiny, crowded dressing room composing music. He was writing a song tentatively titled "If Your Mama Could See You Now," even while the dressing-room door kept swinging open to admit his fiancee, his half-brother, his manager...
